questions.text: A person when the Image is known to form behind the retina is suffering from:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypermetropia Hypermetropia (hyperopia) or longsightedness is the refractive state of the eye wherein parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina with the accommodation being at rest Clinical features Symptoms: Asymptomatic. Asthenopic symptoms. Defective vision with asthenopic symptoms. Defective vision only. Effect of ageing on vision ageing, due to a decrease in accommodative power, hypermetropia becomes manifest. To begin with, blurring occurs for near vision and then for distant vision also.

Highyeild:

Signs 1. Size of the eyeball may appear small 2. Cornea appears smaller 3. Anterior chamber is shallow. 4. Retinoscopy and auto refractometry reveal hypermetropic refractive error. 5. Fundus examination reveals a small optic disc which may look more vascular with ill-defined margins and may simulate papillitis (though there is no swelling of the disc, so it is called pseudo papillitis). The retina as a whole may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections (shot silk appearance). 6. A-scan ultrasonography (biometry) reveal a short anteroposterior length of the eyeball in axial hypermetropia.

Extraedge:

Grading of hypermetropia Low hypermetropia, when the error is < + 2D. Moderate hypermetropia, when the error is between +2 to + 5D. High hypermetropia, when the error is > + 5D.

questions.text: A false statement about EOG is?

options.label: A
options.text: Activity of RPE and outer segment of photoreceptors

options.label: C
options.text: Any lesion distal to photoreceptor has normal EOG

options.label: D
options.text: Markedly high EOG is seen in the best disease

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arden index < 185 is normal EOG is a measure of standing potential generated due to changes in voltage across the apical and basal membranes of RPE It reflects the activity of RPE and photoreceptors, thus any pathology of the inner retina will have a normal EOG

Highyeild:

Arden s ratio max potential in light/max potential in dark = light peak/ dark trough Normally > 1.85 or 185

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Activity of RPE and outer segment of photoreceptors This is the correct statement, regarding EOG. Option: C. Any lesion distal to the photoreceptor has normal EOG Regarding EOG, this statement is correct. Option: D. Markedly high EOG is seen in the best disease Best disease - Friedrich Best, who presented a detailed pedigree of the disease in 1905, Best vitelliform macular dystrophy , or Best disease, is a hereditary retinal dystrophy involving the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), and leads to a characteristic bilateral yellow “egg-yolk” appearance of the macula.

questions.text: You examine a patient diagnosed with hypermetropia. Which of the following options represents the findings that could be seen in this patient?
questions.correct_answer: B. Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis. Shot silk appearance with pseudopapillitis can be seen on fundus examination of the hypermetropic eye . Shot silk appearance- retina, as a whole, may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections . Pseudopapillitis - a small optic disc, hypervascular, with ill-defined margins without disc edema

Highyeild:

Other signs of hypermetropia include: Small eyeball Small cornea Short anteroposterior length of the eyeball The convex lens (plus lens) is used for the correction of hypermetropia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Pale tessellated appearance with pseudopapillitis - not the correct combination. Option: C. Pale tessellated appearance with papillitis - seen in patients with Option: D. Shot silk appearance with papillitis. - not the correct combination.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male complains of vision distortion The distortion increases progressively in both the meridians and wearing his spectacles. All of the following are correct regarding the patient's problem except:

options.label: A
options.text: It is also called pincushion distortion

options.label: B
options.text: It is due to wearing cylindrical glasses

options.label: C
options.text: It is due to asymmetrical convex lenses in both the eyes

questions.correct_answer: B. It is due to wearing cylindrical glasses
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is due to wearing cylindrical glasses The distortion increases progressively in both the meridians-the diagnosis has to be Aphakia, which causes spherical and prismatic aberrations as a side effect of high power convex spectacles.

Highyeild:

On wearing a cylindrical lens i.e. correction of astigmatism, the distortion should decrease in both the axis, not increase.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. It is also called pincushion distortion - Pincushions are typically filled tightly with stuffing to hold pins rigidly in place. Magnetic pin cushions are also sometimes used; though technically they are not "cushions", they serve the same basic function of holding pins neatly. Option: C. It is due to asymmetrical convex lenses in both the eyes A (general, asymmetric) lens is a lamina formed by the intersection of two offset disks of unequal radii such that the intersection is not empty, one disk does not completely enclose the other, and the centres of curvatures are on opposite sides of the lens. Option: D. It is aniseikonia Aniseikonia is the difference in image size perceived between the eyes from unequal magnification due to either anisometropia or retinal pathology. This can manifest with symptoms of headache, dizziness, disorientation, and excessive eye strain.

Iridodonesis Tremulousness of the iris (iridodonesis) is seen in aphakia .

questions.text: A child is brought to you by his mother complaining that his both eyes seem inwards deviated. On examination, bilateral esotropia is found. The rest of the eye examination is within normal limits. On checking for refraction what is the most likely anomaly to be present?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypermetropia Hypermetropia is the most common refractive error seen in younger age groups with esotropia. Hypermetropia (hyperopia) or longsightedness is the refractive state of the eye wherein parallel rays of light coming from infinity are focused behind the retina with the accommodation being at rest Clinical features Symptoms: Asymptomatic. Asthenopic symptoms. Defective vision with asthenopic symptoms. Defective vision only. Effect of ageing on vision ageing, due to a decrease in accommodative power, hypermetropia becomes manifest. To begin with, blurring occurs for near vision and then for distant vision also.

Highyeild:

Signs 1. Size of the eyeball may appear small 2. Cornea appears smaller 3. Anterior chamber is shallow. 4. Retinoscopy and auto refractometry reveal hypermetropic refractive error. 5. Fundus examination reveals a small optic disc which may look more vascular with ill-defined margins and may simulate papillitis (though there is no swelling of the disc, so it is called pseudo papillitis). The retina as a whole may shine due to the greater brilliance of light reflections (shot silk appearance). 6. A-scan ultrasonography (biometry) reveal a short anteroposterior length of the eyeball in axial hypermetropia.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Myopia is more commonly associated with exotropia in the elder age group. So checking for refractive error becomes the most important step in the management of these patients. Option: B . Lazy eye (amblyopia) is reduced vision in one eye caused by abnormal visual development early in life. The weaker — or lazy — eye often wanders inward or outward. Amblyopia generally develops from birth up to age 7 years . It is the leading cause of decreased vision among children. Rarely, lazy eye affects both eyes. Option: D. equality in refraction in the two eyes.

Extraedge:

Grading of hypermetropia Low hypermetropia, when the error is < + 2D. Moderate hypermetropia, when the error is between +2 to + 5D. High hypermetropia, when the error is > + 5D.
